## Natural history notes

The Ten-angled Pipewort (Eriocaulon decangulare) is an aquatic or semi-aquatic wildflower found in bogs, wet meadows, and shallow ponds across the southeastern United States. It produces slender stalks topped with small, button-like white flower heads that resemble tiny cotton balls. The species’ name refers to the ten subtle ridges, or “angles,” on its flower stalks. Adapted to nutrient-poor, acidic wetlands, it contributes to the delicate plant communities of bog ecosystems.
